case_title: SUHAIL KHAN alias SALEH MUHAMMAD vs THE STATE

accussed_details.name: Suhail Khan alias Saleh Muhammad
allegation: Possession of narcotics (3.64 kg heroin and 2 kg charas)

complaint_summary: Appellant was apprehended at Denso Hall bus stop with narcotics based on spy information. Contraband included heroin and charas. FIR registered under multiple sections of CNS Act, 1997.
investigation_summary: Police patrolling led to arrest based on spy information. Contraband recovered, samples sealed, and FIR registered. Accused disclosed involvement of associates in narcotics trade.
judgment_summary: Conviction for possession of charas upheld, but life imprisonment sentence reduced to time already served. Conviction for heroin possession set aside due to discrepancies in chemical report and evidence.
punishment: Imprisonment already undergone for possession of 2 kg charas; life imprisonment sentence reduced.
Decision_or_verdict: Appeal dismissed with modification of sentence.
legal_arguments: Defense argued discrepancies in FIR timings and chemical report.
Prosecution argued corroboration of witnesses and adherence to legal procedures.
Court noted contradictions in heroin sample weights but upheld charas recovery.
sections: Sections 6 to 9, 12 to 19, and 37 of CNS Act, 1997

witness_statement.H.C. Muhammad Hassan: Mashir of arrest and recovery; corroborated prosecution's case.
witness_statement.S.-I. Ghulam Abbas: Complainant and Investigating Officer; corroborated recovery and arrest details.

maxims.Fair Investigation: Complainant should not act as Investigating Officer to ensure unbiased investigation.

legal_terms.Mashir: Witness to recovery and arrest in criminal cases.
legal_terms.Section 382-B: Benefit of time already served in custody.

summary_vector_notes: Appellant convicted for possession of charas; life imprisonment reduced to time served. Conviction for heroin possession set aside due to evidence discrepancies. Prosecution relied on police witnesses; defense highlighted procedural flaws.
